Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, making it more difficult to achieve food security. We quantify the magnitude of this yield variability for the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries and find that it will be much larger than present-day variability. This variability will increase the probability that these countries will have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year, and it will increase the risk of global food price spikes. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the formation of social hierarchies is still unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is involved in the formation of social hierarchies. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is limited by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple materials that can precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized with irregular shapes and material distributions. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work can inspire the design of mechanical structures with complex behaviors and pave the way for the development of intelligent materials and devices.

The hemoglobin system is a key component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 mRNA-binding protein is a key component of this pathway. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the developing human fetus and that IGF2BP1 silencing in adult erythroid tissues results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a key component of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of many effective therapies, the majority of patients do not respond to treatment, and the disease continues to spread. One of the main reasons for this failure is the development of resistance to therapy. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis in cancer cells, and that this resistance is mediated by the transcriptional activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). Furthermore, we demonstrated that the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These results suggest that the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism involving the N terminus of the Ca2+ sensor STIM1. Our findings provide a mechanism of action of LCCBs and suggest that caution should be exercised in the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling. This study may help to reduce the risk of adverse cardiovascular events in patients treated with LCCBs. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way federal land was managed for biodiversity. We show that the NWFP has not yet achieved its goals. The policy halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area was stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need for more effective monitoring of the effects of forest policy. This study provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. We hope that our findings will inform future policy development. (Show more)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The best compounds are synthetically more accessible, exhibit higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and are up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. These results demonstrate the potential of our design strategy to develop new antibiotics. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results suggest that the proposed architecture is a promising alternative to existing architectures for many problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for the development of new applications in computer vision.

Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This was not fatal, but led to the development of organ-specific autoantibodies. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to induce the diseases in recipient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency is a valuable tool to study the role of Treg cells in the development of autoimmunity. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. (Show more)

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive view of the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impact of plant feeding on beetle diversification. We show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. Our approach can also be applied to engineering other protein molecules, such as enzymes and receptors. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a unique part of the Earth that is not well understood. One of the most important questions is how the inner core formed. The present study shows that the inner core formed by a two-step process. First, the bcc phase of iron nucleated, and then the hcp phase nucleated from the bcc phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the Earth and other planets. It also provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors associated with chronic marijuana use.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing are also the most predictive of the brain’s responses to language. These results provide computational and neuroscientific support for the view that language comprehension in the human brain is fundamentally a predictive process.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still in its infancy. One of the main reasons is that the training of deep networks is unstable, even though the universal approximation theorem guarantees that any function can be approximated arbitrarily well. We show that this instability is due to the fact that there are problems in scientific computing where no algorithm can find a stable solution, even though the theorem does not forbid it. We introduce a new class of algorithms, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which are stable and can find a solution to a given accuracy with only a few iterations. We prove that only a few layers are needed for an accurate solution. Our results provide a classification of conditions under which stable networks can be computed by an algorithm. They also provide a new perspective on the stability of neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. In 1975, a classic experiment was conducted to study the effect of exponential growth on people’s behavior. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not noticed until 2020, when the pandemic was still ongoing. This case study is a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are very similar in size, genome content, and gene content. However, they have different hosts and cause different diseases. This study shows that they have been evolving together for thousands of years and that they are still very similar. This suggests that they have retained many of the same functions, and that they may still cause similar diseases in the future.

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also central to the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. However, the dynamics of these quantities is still poorly understood for interacting systems. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work paves the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and there is a need for a safe and effective vaccine. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs. This vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In addition, the vaccine candidate has a furin cleavage site deletion to further improve safety. In hamsters, the vaccine candidate is more than 90% protective against lethal challenge with SARS-CoV-2. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. Thus, the vaccine candidate described here may be a valuable addition to the arsenal of COVID-19 vaccines. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets or by the bite of infected fleas. However, the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is characterized by recurrent outbreaks, which are difficult to explain with the current knowledge of plague transmission. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the historical mortality curves. Our results suggest that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides new insights into the history of plague and the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of this disease. It also highlights the importance of studying the historical epidemiology of diseases, which can help us to understand the past and inform the present.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in biology. However, the evolution of brain size is biased by the size of the animal. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is better understood by analyzing the number of neurons rather than by mass. The results show that the evolution of the brain is characterized by four major shifts in the number of neurons. The most important shift is the increase in the number of neurons in birds and mammals, which is a result of the evolution of the neocortex.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a more complete understanding of the role of TRAP1 in mitochondria and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is also a promising drug target for cancer treatment. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is not understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binding to actin filaments enhances the rate of severing, and that this enhancement is enhanced by a mechanical torque. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a molecular understanding of ADF’s action and may lead to the design of new drugs. They also have implications for our understanding of the action of other proteins that use mechanical forces to regulate their action.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by insulin. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on health and for developing strategies to reduce the risk of obesity and its complications. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce genetic structure in the population. Finally, we find that the genetic structure is not only a consequence of the admixture, but also of the geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. This study provides a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with the other person. This is a form of emotional contagion, and it is not limited to in-person interactions. We also show that people can be influenced by the emotions of others without being aware of it. This suggests that people may be influenced by the emotions of others without realizing it, and that they may be influenced by the emotions of others without even being aware of it.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but their impact on mRNA function has only recently been appreciated. We show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on the translation of the mRNA. This finding has implications for understanding the role of Ψ in mRNA function and for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social engagement, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are independent of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and prosperity. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may therefore be a key factor in promoting healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a long-standing and poorly understood pattern. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic medium to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a consequence of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of this temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibited a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlated with significantly higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. We also found that stimulation of primary airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C led to greater IFN induction at 37 °C relative to 33 °C at early time points poststimulation and to a sustained increase in the induction of ISGs at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must respond to the signals they receive. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This sensing mechanism is important for the bacterium to maintain its attachment to the surface, and to activate a number of virulence factors. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems, and may have implications for the development of new antibiotics.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the quality of surface waters is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide contamination of surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that the virus has spread between deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. However, the immune response in AD is still poorly understood. Here, we show that neurons are the main source of inflammatory factors in the brain, and that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain is the main trigger of this response. Our results suggest that the immune response in AD may be more complex than previously thought, and that it may be a key player in the pathogenesis of the disease. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. (Show more)

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of the maltose binding protein. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistep process, with a fast step and a slow step. The fast step is a transition state that is common to many segments of the protein. The slow step is unique to the protein.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, often described as alarmones because their cellular concentration increases in response to stress, have recently been shown to function in bacteria as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. Removal of this cap is critical for initiating 5′ end-dependent degradation of those RNAs, potentially affecting bacterial adaptability to stress. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unique manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We found that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study could also be extended to other inflammatory conditions. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of the biomass of different taxa is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can self-regulate their dynamics. SOC systems are characterized by a critical state, where the system is neither too slow nor too fast, and by a power-law distribution of activity. The power-law distribution is a signature of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and difficult to process. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, or made to have a metallic electronic structure, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, or made to have a semiconducting electronic structure, without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings also provide a platform for machine learning of the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work is expected to advance the understanding of the structure and properties of diamond, and to promote its applications.

The discovery of the antimicrobial activity of legume nodule-specific peptides has opened up a new class of compounds with potential for use in agriculture. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the structure of a unique NCR peptide, the antifungal activity of this class of peptides against plant fungal pathogens, and their potential for use as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex. Although the male reproductive axis has been extensively studied, the female reproductive axis is poorly understood. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. Platelet adhesion and aggregation are critical for hemostasis. We show that force on the surface of platelets can switch the conformation of VWF, allowing it to bind to platelets more rapidly. This is important for hemostasis, as it allows platelets to adhere and aggregate in the presence of bleeding.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses from human samples, which can be used to study the human virome. We find that viruses are associated with a wide variety of diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and autism. These results provide a foundation for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the interaction process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The instrument can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the instrument by conducting observations over Beijing. The observations show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is determined by the balance between the amount of solar energy absorbed and the amount of energy lost to space. The temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past is more difficult to determine, but is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. We show that the temperature of the Earth’s surface has decreased over geological time.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that C-type inactivation in BK channels is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel regulation. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the world today. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a number of mechanisms to prime the RBC surface, altering the biophysical properties of the cell and reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our current understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without defects or impurities, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without defects or impurities, by applying pressure. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to contribute to the development of diamond-based devices and applications. This work is expected to contribute to the development of diamond-based devices and applications.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the mechanisms of dry air-induced disease pathology and may lead to the development of new strategies to mitigate influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words as it processes a sentence. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s response to a sentence varies with each word, but suddenly increases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with the idea that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to identify the structure of a sentence. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our findings have implications for theories of language acquisition and for the design of artificial intelligence. (Show more)

The Wnt signaling pathway is one of the most important pathways in development. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently in different tissues. This differential regulation may be important for tissue-specific responses.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the causes are not well understood. Here we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, a region of the brain that is important in feeding, causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons in a region of the brain that is important in feeding, the substantia nigra. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the mechanisms that govern hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a target for the development of new treatments for obesity. Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural regions. Thus, there is a need for sustainable methods to increase nitrogen availability for plant growth. One promising approach is to use engineered bacteria that can fix nitrogen in the atmosphere. However, the bacteria must be able to colonize the roots of the desired host plant, and they must be able to avoid the plant roots of other species. Here, we report the development of a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria’s interaction with the host plant.

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that community-based monitoring programs can contribute to sustainable forest management, but the effectiveness of such programs depends on the quality of the early deforestation alerts and the ability of the community to act on the alerts.

Animals have evolved a wide variety of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an auditory organ that is not part of its body. Instead, the spider has outsourced its hearing to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The web is made of protein and is self-manufactured by the spider. The web is so sensitive that it can detect the motion of a single air particle. The spider can also adjust the size of the web to its needs. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors. It also provides a unique model for studying regenerative sensing and the design of novel acoustic flow detectors. (Show more)

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. Aerosols affect the hydrologic cycle, contributing to water and food security. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies. The development of vaccines is a critical step in ending the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD sequence that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered sequence can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria, minimizing the cost of manufacturing. We also report the design and synthesis of a virus-like particle (VLP) that can present the engineered RBD sequence. This engineered sequence and VLP can be used to develop vaccines that can be manufactured at large scale, potentially providing a cost-effective and accessible vaccine for low- and middle-income countries. This work provides a potential solution to the global vaccine access crisis.

The ligand–receptor interaction between anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and secreted small ALKAL proteins (FAM150, AUG) is implicated in the pathogenesis of neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of neural crest-derived tissues. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALKALs activate the zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro and in vivo. We further show that loss-of-function alleles of zebrafish ALKALs cause iridophore loss in zebrafish larvae and lethality in adults. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings contribute to our understanding of the role of ALKALs in human cancer and in the development of the neural crest. They also provide a zebrafish model system for studying the role of ALKALs in neural crest development. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been a constant threat to humanity for millennia. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of genomes from this period are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. These data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work also provides a snapshot of the diversity of Y. pestis in the past, which can be used to better understand the pathogen’s evolution and ecology in the present. This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and beyond.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical component of climate-smart agriculture. However, the management practices that can maximize SOC storage on grasslands remain uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage on grasslands. These results are consistent with a meta-analysis of published studies comparing the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on Mollisols worldwide. Our findings highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and highlight the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the role of grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose a risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans and used this to rank 887 viruses from 74,635 animals. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a framework for the systematic identification and prioritization of viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. It is a critical step in the process of identifying and mitigating the risk of future viral threats.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We also identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of red nectar in plants. This work provides a molecular basis for the evolution of red nectar in plants.

We present a study of the genetic structure of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the 5th/6th century AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of these women is highly heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that the collective genetic ancestry of the women suggests that they originated in southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. We describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We found that mNGS can be used to investigate undifferentiated fevers in resource-scarce settings, where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. We also found that mNGS can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in eukaryotic DNA replication. This study also provides a unique insight into the role of the sliding clamp in the structure and function of the polymerase. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In this paper, we describe a method for the in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules from an RNA template. This method can be used to reconstruct the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in understanding the spatial distribution of economic and social outcomes.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe COVID-19 had high levels of inflammatory cytokines and immune cells in the blood, and the patients had a high mortality rate. We also found that the patients with severe COVID-19 had a high level of IL-6 in the blood, and the patients had a high mortality rate. We then found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, could reduce the mortality rate in severe COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new therapeutic strategy for COVID-19. It is expected that this study will provide a reference for the treatment of COVID-19 in the future.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its homeostasis is challenging due to its high toxicity. The existence of natural products that bind copper and impact cellular copper content is unknown in eukaryotes. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide compounds that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. Xanthocillin-derived compounds have significant antimicrobial properties, and the copper-chelating properties of these compounds are demonstrated in Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a drill sample of laminated mudstone (Buckskin) at the base of the Gale crater sequence in the Spirit of Mars region of Mars Science Laboratory’s Curiosity rover is significant because it is the first detection of tridymite on another planet. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment is consistent with the formation of the sedimentary sequence. The presence of amorphous precipitated silica, and possibly the crystalline magnetite (otherwise detrital) are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The diagenesis of these solutions is consistent with the observed sequence of sedimentary structures.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is increasing in many regions. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is strongly associated with the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are strongly associated with the region in which they grow. Our results suggest that the resistance strategies of trees are a key factor in their ability to survive LSFs, and that the resistance strategies of trees are strongly associated with the region in which they grow. This suggests that the resistance strategies of trees can be used to forecast the vulnerability of forests to LSFs. Our results can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear what role these cells play in the pathogenesis of the disease. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains an IL-17A+ phenotype and is unable to induce colitis in recipients, whereas the other subset can induce colitis and is dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the only cells in the human body that do not have the ability to divide. We report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. This method allows rapid production of large quantities of astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease and screen for therapeutics. This study will help us to better understand the disease and develop new therapies. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to humans. We now demonstrate that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the vector, the Ixodes scapularis tick, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by inducing the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The presence of a pygostyle, a short tail bone, is a defining feature of the modern bird group. However, the origin of the pygostyle is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early members of the group. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known diversity of early pygostylians and adds important information about the origin of the avian tail.

We show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. However, some vertebrates have distinctive blue-green colors, which are caused by unusually high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in the blood. We show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, have absorption spectra that mimic those of phytochromes and bacteriophytochromes. Our results provide molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular basis for the presence of blue-green colors in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified as either luminal or basal, based on their expression of luminal or basal markers, respectively. Basal breast cancer cells are more aggressive and are more likely to metastasize. Hypoxia is a feature of the tumor microenvironment, and hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α are important regulators of the tumor microenvironment. We show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which is a m6A demethylase, and that ALKBH5 expression is dependent on HIF-1α and HIF-2α. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in breast cancer cells, and ALKBH5 expression is required for the tumorigenic potential of breast cancer cells. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in breast cancer cells is dependent on hypoxia, and ALKBH5 expression is required for the tumorigenic potential of breast cancer cells. These findings may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (truncated)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily torn. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of other materials used in the production of books. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the causes and consequences of the event. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery of the carbon cycle is punctuated by multiple events of rapid change. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms, and will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overproduction of proinflammatory cytokines and the dysregulation of the immune response. The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the environment, and the intestinal immune system is tightly regulated by the intestinal epithelial cells. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD.
