The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in two variants that are currently circulating. We find that the more infectious variant contains a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the structural basis of the increased infectivity of the currently circulating variants. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.6 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 79.6 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the importance of addressing structural inequalities in order to reduce the burden of COVID-19 and improve health outcomes in the United States.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that these properties can be used to predict and explain the formation of unexpected compounds and crystal structures under pressure. Our results provide a new perspective on the chemical properties of atoms and their evolution with pressure. They also provide a predictive model for the formation of exotic compounds and crystal structures under pressure. This model can be used to explore the chemical properties of atoms in the future.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a large effect on the carbon cycle, and that this effect can offset some of the warming caused by greenhouse gases. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowing down, rather than speeding up, in some regions. This has important implications for the management of fire and carbon in the future.

The immune system of the squid Euprymna scolopes is a complex, multilayered system that is able to respond to a wide variety of threats. In this study, we show that the immune system of this host is also able to regulate the activities of a symbiotic community of bacteria. We show that the squid immune system is able to provide a specific glycan to the bacteria, which is then metabolized by the bacteria to enhance their ability to produce light at night. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is active, and is not required for the bacteria to survive. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the immune system in the maintenance of mutualistic symbioses. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify the latent patterns that describe them. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We find that the narratives contain topics that are not captured by the structured variables used to summarize the data. We also find that the topics are gendered, and that the gender bias of the topics is correlated with the gender of the victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. We hope that it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were the result of repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results provide evidence for the existence of climate-driven reintroductions of the plague bacterium into Europe, and suggest that the disease was not introduced into Europe as a result of a single event. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and on the role of climate in the spread of infectious diseases. It also highlights the importance of climate in the spread of pathogens in the past, and in the present.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, and their loss can have significant ecological and economic consequences. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of sea stars (asteroids) in the Northeast Pacific. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of this group of animals.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof of principle that IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the population. Finally, we show that the settlement of Madagascar was not homogeneous, but happened in different regions of the island, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent events. This study provides a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a proof-of-concept for the application of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. This approach can potentially be extended to other protein molecules, including those used in vaccines. Our approach can also be extended to other applications in drug discovery and development.

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, providing information on crop status that is used to manage production and to provide food security. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily used in quantitative analyses. We show that the information provided by crop experts can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this approach can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our approach can be easily extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a gradual change in the selection pressure on the genome. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the genome, and that the extent of the relaxation is linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle is a gradual process, with bursts of gene losses coinciding with periods of relaxed selection. The evolutionary rates in the retained functional complexes are several times higher than the background rate, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. This model can be used to infer the evolutionary history of the plastid genome and to reconstruct the macroevolutionary history of the host. This information is crucial for understanding the origin and evolution of photosynthesis.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water security. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in southwestern South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This study provides a quantitative assessment of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of extreme droughts, which is critical for the development of adaptation strategies. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, is a significant step forward in our understanding of the history of quasicrystals.

(Bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in photosynthesis, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. Here, we show that the two enzymes are part of a single family, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of the enzyme in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. We propose that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings may provide insights into the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities. We also find that the probability of drought years is more than twice as likely to occur when conditions are warm. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of drought years in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is still not fully understood. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral deficits in autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 cause severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which cause hematological abnormalities and muscle disease. Our data suggest that dysregulated CRAC channel signaling is a common pathologic feature in Stormorken syndrome and related conditions, and that these mutations can be used as a tool to understand the molecular function of the CRAC channel. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a transcellular manner, and that this spreading is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the spread of aggregates is important for the development of disease pathology. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections. These findings are of great importance for the prevention and control of viral diseases in bats and humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and have shown that they are effective in vitro and in vivo. We have also shown that the one-carbon unit donor, formate, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We have further shown that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a metabolic deficiency of cancer cells that can be targeted therapeutically. This study provides a framework for the development of a therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or treatment. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS is a consequence of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This finding may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. This device configuration can be deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The research presented here focuses on a plant, Montsechia vidalii, first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. The study of more than 1,000 specimens of Montsechia reveals that it is an aquatic flowering plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it is the sister to Ceratophyllum.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, as well as to society. Here we present the genomes of ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. They also provide a historical perspective on the impact of B19V on human health. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This study shows that the acceleration is due to the melting of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets, and that the rate of rise is increasing because the melting is increasing. The study also shows that the rate of rise is now greater than the rate of rise during the 1970s and 1980s, and that it is likely to continue to increase in the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that this increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment or vaccine for MERS. Here, we show that the antiviral remdesivir, which is in clinical use for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment is effective both prophylactically and therapeutically, and may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of continued research into the development of effective antiviral treatments for MERS and other coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. The immune system of the squid Euprymna scolopes is a complex, multilayered system that is able to respond to a wide variety of threats. One of the most important components of the immune system is the immune cell, called a hemocyte, which is able to respond to a variety of threats. In this study, we show that the immune system of the squid is able to respond to a specific glycan, which is secreted by the symbiotic bacteria of the squid. This glycan is secreted by the symbiotic bacteria at a specific time of day, and the immune system of the squid responds to this secretion. This study provides a new perspective on the immune system of the squid, and it also provides a new perspective on the symbiosis between the squid and its symbiotic bacteria. (Show more)

Suspension rates in schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with negative consequences for students, teachers, and society. We show that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this can be sustained over time. We also show that this mindset can be taught to students, and that it can be used to reduce suspension rates. These findings have implications for the future of schools and for the future of our children.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can cause transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that block sequential proteolysis of the spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This study provides insights into the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection and may help to identify strategies to control this deadly pathogen. (PsycInfo Database Record (

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the world’s population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing this impact. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a catering service can have a significant impact on sales, with little impact on overall sales or rebound effects. These results suggest that simple changes to catering practices could make a major contribution to reducing environmental degradation and improving population health. The results also suggest that the physical environment in which people make decisions can be used to promote more sustainable diets and better health. This approach could be used to influence the food choices of people in other settings, such as schools and hospitals.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to study the surfaceome, the set of proteins that are exposed to the extracellular space. We have applied this method to study the surfaceome of a panel of oncogenic breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics, and find massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for studying the surfaceome in other cell types and cancer types. This work also provides a resource for the cancer research community to study the surfaceome of their own cancer cell lines. This work is also a proof of principle for the use of AI-ETD for glycoproteomics.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with no specific treatment or vaccine available. The viral accessory protein ORF8 has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response, and has been the focus of several studies. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the immune evasion activities of ORF8 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of many diseases. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats. We also show that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

We live in an age of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to make sense of the data and draw reasonable conclusions. We describe a set of new methods for making inferences from data that have been “cherry picked”—that is, searched for the strongest associations. The methods are based on the idea that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. We illustrate the methods with three examples: forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are important for blood flow and vascular homeostasis. However, the generation of ECs is difficult, and the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the generation of endothelial cells from human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-transduced fibroblasts can form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Furthermore, ETV2-transduced fibroblasts significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In the past few years, two additional RTKs have been identified as oncogenes, and their ligands have been discovered. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between these oncogenes and their ligands. We show that the ligands of these two additional RTKs play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. These experiments establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are required for zebrafish pigment development. These findings provide insights into the physiological roles of these oncogenes and their ligands. They also provide a model system for studying the role of ligand-activated RTKs in vivo. This study may also help in the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING deficiency alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis suggested that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of T2D and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza A viruses are the most important pathogens of humans and animals. They are divided into two major groups, which differ in the number of segments in their genome. The group of eight-segmented viruses is responsible for most human infections. The genome of this group is packaged in a selective manner, in which one copy of each RNA segment is packaged into each virion. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. We show that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome is based on a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we identified a critical role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the development of atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in understanding the spatial distribution of economic and social outcomes.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the time between cell infection and viral production is likely short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak median viral load and shorten the time to undetectable viral load, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can help guide the development of effective treatment strategies for ZIKV. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of anthropogenic and natural stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is currently observed in many parts of the world. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that separates the host from the external environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky, allowing the spread of cancer cells into the body. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can also influence the composition of the microbiome, which in turn can influence the tumor growth. We also show that the activity of the JNK signaling pathway can be used as a therapeutic target to control the growth of intestinal tumors and restore the integrity of the intestinal barrier. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This knowledge can be used to develop new strategies to treat intestinal tumors. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to it. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, inhibit the growth of breast cancer patient-derived xenografts, and improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still debated. We show that a series of massive volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica. These changes likely triggered a rapid, nearly synchronous, and widespread acceleration in Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our map of global riverine fisheries can be used to identify regions where fisheries are a high priority for conservation and sustainable use. This can help to protect both food security and species diversity. Our data can also be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,

The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of the adult nervous system. In the past decade, we have learned that the adult CNS is capable of regenerating, but the molecular mechanisms that control this process are largely unknown. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the proper development of all organisms. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences, and the location of these binding sites is of great interest. Here, we describe the location of these binding sites in the flowering plant Mimulus guttatus.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing the activity of a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant component of the metabolic resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant component is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network function was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. In healthy subjects, and in early Parkinson’s disease, network deactivation was observed. In contrast, in advanced Parkinson’s disease, network activation was observed. These results provide a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. They also provide a means of assessing the functional significance of the changes in brain organization that occur in Parkinson’s disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In this study, we identify a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap in the genomes of yeast and humans. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that the cap is produced cotranscriptionally, suggesting that it may play a role in regulating the stability and translation of specific classes of mRNA.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of a recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC is unknown. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Thus, our study provides insights into the role of FSIP1 in TNBC and

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant number of alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a target in the management of this disorder.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile compounds, many of which are nitrogenous. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the biosynthesis of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of the Earth’s ecosystems. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changed as temperatures deviated from ambient conditions. This change in the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning was driven by two processes. First, more diverse communities were more likely to include species with thermal traits that enabled them to maintain productivity as temperatures shifted from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This study highlights the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is particularly important in the context of climate change, where the effects of global warming are expected to be more severe in the tropics.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit, and its neurons are thought to encode spatial information. However, the anatomical and functional organization of the neurons in MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the neurons in MEC are organized in a topographic fashion, and their activity is modulated by the location of the animal. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and suggest that the neurons in MEC are organized in a topographic fashion, and their activity is modulated by the location of the animal. This study provides a foundation for future studies of the function of the MEC.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This is a unique means of flowering regulation, which is likely to be important for the synchronization of flowering of the host and parasite.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons, but the underlying cause is unknown. Here, we show that the dopamine-producing neurons are connected to a specialized system within the nigral system, the striatonigral system, which is affected in the disease. We also show that the dopamine-containing neurons are connected to a specialized system within the nigral system, the striosome–dendron bouquets, which are also affected in the disease. Our results suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine-producing neurons.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of the connection between two people, and it is used by the people themselves to gauge their own connection to others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining a stable heart rate in the face of changes in the environment. The SAN is composed of a group of cardiomyocytes that are responsible for generating the heart rate. These cardiomyocytes are called sinoatrial (SAN) cells. SAN cells are responsible for maintaining a stable heart rate in the face of changes in the environment.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated for decades. Although Si has been shown to enhance plant resistance against abiotic stresses, the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well documented. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for the management of insect pests. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings may have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in human macrophages and for the treatment of phenylketonuria. They also suggest that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase may be a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of plant biotechnology.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unmonitored. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to large water bodies, and that their nutrient inputs are more biologically available to algae. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable coastal ecosystems. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of particles in a random potential, and we show that the network dynamics can be understood as a special case of a more general class of systems.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis causes changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous brain activity, which can be explained by changes in the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain. We also show that these changes are sufficient to cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the spectral composition of spontaneous brain activity may be a useful biomarker for the diagnosis and monitoring of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This may help to improve the clinical management of this devastating disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming, and it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past. We present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a global warming of ∼10 °C, a doubling of atmospheric CO2, and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. This study highlights the importance of certification in the palm oil industry and the need for more rigorous monitoring of certification impacts. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The exocyst complex is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved in plants and animals, but the mechanism of regulation is not well understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a key component of the evolution of sex differences. In this study, we investigate the effects of a single genetic locus on the secondary sexual characteristics of a fish species with multiple interacting sex determination alleles. We find that the interaction of sex determination alleles produces a modular system of sexual dimorphism, where the same locus can produce different phenotypes in different individuals. This modular system of sexual dimorphism provides context for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the presence of iron is known to promote oxidative damage. However, the retina is also a tissue that is rich in iron, and the consequences of this iron overload are not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of iron in the retina promotes the formation of bisretinoids, which are a class of oxidized retinal pigments that are implicated in age-related macular degeneration. We also show that the presence of iron in the retina can promote the photooxidation and photodegradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and other retinal diseases. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is not only possible, but also linked to morphological innovation. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological innovations, and that the evolution of specialization is a key step in the diversification of food webs. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly evolved structure. The fossil record of the human hand is incomplete, and the origin of some of its key derived features is poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. The timing of the evolution of this feature is important for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like tool use. This study also highlights the importance of East African fossil sites for understanding the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, which we use to identify a role for SHMT in cancer. We show that SHMT is required for colon cancer tumor growth, and that a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT is effective in a cancer cell-line screen. We also show that a deficiency in glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously difficult to treat. Thus, our work identifies a metabolic target for cancer therapy, and a cancer type that is uniquely dependent upon this target. This work also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT in the clinic.

The world is facing a food crisis, and the agricultural sector is the main focus of attention. However, little attention is paid to the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. This study shows that deforestation can have negative effects on people’s diets, and that this effect is exacerbated when forests are fragmented. The results have important implications for policy makers, as forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest land animals that walked Earth. We show that this increase in weight has led to a significant increase in subsoil compaction, which now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that this trend is a result of the lack of ecological constraints on the roaming of sauropods, which would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. Our results suggest that the roaming of sauropods may have been a key factor in the decline of these giants, and that the ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the importance of considering the effects of mechanization on soil ecology, and the need for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits.
